title: 6 things you need to know about Ashtanga Yoga
description: New to Ashtanga yoga?  Looking for top tips for Ashtanga yoga practice? Here are a collection of 6 things we wish we knew before embarking on this special practice that is loved and practised by many fellow yogis worldwide.

description._content:
Sri Krishna Pattabhi Jois (1915-2009]

Guruji passed away, May 18, 2009, in Mysore, India

He founded the Ashtanga Yoga Research Institute in Mysore, India, which today draws large numbers of devoted adepts from around the globe. Jois's Ashtanga Vinyasa Yoga method draws its name from the concept of ashtanga that hails from from the Yoga Sutra of Patanjali, the ancient Sanskrit text that is the primary reference for the darshan of yoga. 

“Do your practice and all is coming.”



I ground myself before the knowing one
Looking for the safety of pure radiance
Somewhere I can shelter from myself
Releasing the whirling of the cascading mind

I look to Patanjali
May I be strong enough to be truly vulnerable
Remind me that the light I search for is within me
Help me to remember that we are the same
Om

data.text: Ashtanga yoga (or Ashtanga Vinayasa Yoga) was developed and popularised by the late Krishna Pattabhi Jois since the 1940s.  Jois developed Ashtanga Yoga not just as a sequence of postures, but a system that combines the use of sequences of postures (asanas), breathing techniques (pranayama), use of internal muscles (bandhas) and gaze points (dristis) for focus.  At first, Ashtanga Yoga can feel a bit intimidating (how I can remember all these postures while looking at the right spots and breathing in the right way?).  Fear not.  A good Ashtanga teacher breaks down the sequence and will teach you one posture at a time, until you are ready to learn more.  However in a big led-class, you may receive less individual attention that you need before you get a hang of the flow and the speed of the practice.  If you find it hard to keep up, it is perfectly normal.  It may worth first sign up to an Ashtanga beginner course before you join a group class, or to attend a 'Mysore' style class which leads us to the next point.
The above diagram shows the primary sequence of the practice.

2. Ashtanga Yoga encourages morning self practices with the guidance of your teacher

Because of the sequenced nature of Ashtanga yoga, there are many ways to learn the practice.  As a beginner, you may want to check out the following options:

Option (1):  Attend a beginner's Ashtanga course that usually consists of weekly classes of 5-10 weeks to learn about the basics.

Option (2): Attend a 'Mysore' morning practice.  You may see that for some yoga studios and gyms, there is an early practice option (and occasionally evening) called Mysore practice.  Mysore is actually the founding location of Ashtanga yoga, and that in the ashram in Mysore, students usually drop in during early mornings within a given period to practice Ashtanga yoga through the guidance of the resident teachers.  In modern day studios, the time frame is usually set between 6am-10am and you can drop in any time and leave any time.  If you are new to the practice or the studio, a good teacher will greet you and adapt the practice for your level.  A lot of practitioners swear by Mysore self-practice as the group energy in the room is usually very focused and inspiring, and also you get the attention of the teacher for poses you need the most.

Option (3): Attend a led, mixed-level class

It is always a good idea to suss out which options work for you best, however it important to note that there are people who get frustrated when they choose option 3 as their first exposure to Ashtanga.  Because everyone has a different body and that a led-class only provides one speed for all those postures, as a beginner to Ashtanga or a complete beginner to yoga, it can sometimes be too much.  To give Ashtanga yoga a fair chance, you may want to start with option (1) or (2).
A yoga teacher giving hands-on adjustment during a Mysore practice to a student to help him move further into the pose.
3.  Hands-on, physical adjustment is integral to Ashtanga Yoga practice

One very unique trait of Ashtanga yoga is that teachers in Ashtanga yoga provide hands-on, physical adjustments.  In a led-class, you will experience less adjustments as a teacher needs to take care of a whole class of students while leading the class verbally and demonstrates when necessary.  But in traditional Mysore practice, a teacher will learn and observe the body type of a student, and provide necessary adjustment through the use of his/her own body as leverage and props.

link.title: Ashtanga Yoga with Ryan Spielman | classes | workshops | yoga ...
link.description: Ashtanga Yoga with Ryan Spielman | classes | workshops | yoga

data.text: A teacher helping a student get further into prasarita padottanasana.

Remember, YOU are ultimately the one who knows your body the most.  When a teacher helps you push you edge further and that you achieve more than what you thought you could, it is one of the most satisfying and exhilarating feeling (the first time my head could touch the floor in prasarita padottanasana like the student above was through the adjustment of a teacher that I trust and practiced with for over 3 years).  However, I have practised with other yogis who have injured through forceful adjustments from their teachers.  It is a fine line between pushing over the edge and over-doing a pose, and you have to trust yourself and also to learn where your limit is.  And it is okay to let your teacher know if you feel like you are being pushed too far.

Below is a video of how Adjustments were made by the late Pattabhi Jois:

video.title: PATTABHI JOIS: When do Ashtanga Yoga Adjustments cross the line?

data.text: As you can see some adjustments can be quite strong, but not all teachers teach the same.  Hence it is vital that you practise around to find a teacher that syncs with you the most.
4. Ashtanga Yoga is about a huge international community of practitioners

One thing I really like about my own Ashtanga yoga practice is that my teacher is very dedicated to his practice and he is also a very compassionate practitioner.  Whenever he could find time, he would visit Mysore to deepen his practice.  The dedication is both inspiring and infectious.  Throughout the years I started meeting more Ashtanga yogi devotees, and it is a very moving, almost religious (in terms of vigor and passion) community for the practice.  Check out the following videos to find out more about the practice:

video.title: Mysore Magic - TRAILER
video.description: What is that indefinable energy that attracts Yoga practitioners back to Mysore, India year after year? There is something that cannot be...

data.text:
5. Depending on how you count, there can be 3-6 series of Ashtanga Yoga

And they are absolutely mind-blowing.

6 things you need to know about Ashtanga Yoga

New to Ashtanga yoga? Looking for top tips for Ashtanga yoga practice? Here are a collection of 6 things we wish we knew before embarking on this special practice that is loved and practised by many fellow yogis worldwide.

    One thing I really like about my own Ashtanga yoga practice is that my teacher is very dedicated to his practice and he is also a very compassionate practitioner.  Whenever he could find time, he would visit Mysore to deepen his practice.  The dedication is both inspiring and infectious.  Throughout the years I started meeting more Ashtanga yogi devotees, and it is a very moving, almost religious (in terms of vigor and passion) community for the practice.  Check out the following videos to find out more about the practice:

    5. Depending on how you count, there can be 3-6 series of Ashtanga Yoga

    And they are absolutely mind-blowing.

    6.  Ashtanga Yoga also can mean the 8 limbs of yoga

    This part is a little bit confusing because Ashtanga yoga usually is referred to the form of yoga described above populated by Pattabhi Jois and his students since his practice with Krishnamacharya from 1927.  However if you trace the origin of the word 'Ashtanga', you will find that it was term coined by Patanjali's Yoga Sutra, the eightfold path is called ashtanga, which literally means "eight limbs".  They are 8 different sets of practices and principles to observe by in order for one to reach the true state of being.  You can read more from this Yoga Journal article.  Hence sometimes people differentiate Patanjali's 8 limbs of Yoga as Ashtanga yoga, and the system developed by Jois as Ashtanga Vinayasa Yoga.

    That's our top insights.  Surely we must have missed something important?  Help us by leaving comments or even photos/videos to help other yogis discover this wonderful practice!  

    Thank you!

    Po
    Founder
    LotsofYoga.  x

    Further references on Ashtanga yoga:
    1. More about the Shri K Pattabhi Jois Ashtanga Yoga Institute.
    2. A great Pinterest board with all things Ashtanga.
    3. Ashtanga yoga as described by Wikipedia and Yoga Journal.  Also check out this very well thought-out, potentially controversial piece on what Ashtanga yoga means to a long-term practitioner, Norman Blair.
    4. I love videos from David Swenson - I used to fall so behind in my first Ashtanga classes and I used David's videos to get familiarised with the sequence before I stepped back into the studio again.  And it worked!
    5.  Found this lovely blog on this lady's personal Ashtanga journey, heartfelt and humble, it is inspiring and warming.
    6.  An interesting blog post: Is Ashtanga dangerous?  Best bits is in the comment section.
    7.  For those of you who thought that women have less upper body strength or are more used to seeing men demonstrating advanced Ashtanga postures, here's a treat for you!  Laruga Glaser's youtube channel features some amazing moves through over 15 years of daily practice.  Such as this one:

    PPS: A beautiful interview with Laruga on her personal journey to Ashtanga.  My favourite quote,

    'Encountering the unknown and opening up to our inherent potential is much more then simply bending the body. It is within the daily discipline that this potential awakens as it points us to a more fulfilling place than we could ever imagine for ourselves. '  - Laura Glaser

    Follow us to keep up to date on all things special about yoga: twitter.com/lotsofyoga or facebook.com/lotsofyoga.  Nameste!
